title: We tested a new ChatGPT-detector for teachers. It flagged an innocent student.

last_post.content:
Numerous sources claim that TurnItIn has a generative AI detector with something like 98% sensitivity and 99% specificity.

For example, the Washington Post, below.

This is completely implausible given that OpenAI themselves only claim to be able to achieve 26% sensitivity and 91% specificity.

So where does this wild claim come from? I think I've figured it out.

https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2023/04/01/chatgpt-cheating-detection-turnitin/

#LLM# #generativeAI #aiDetection #chatGPT#

The surprising part is not that math grad students named Cox and Zucker would come up with the idea of writing a paper together just as a joke.

It's that they followed through after they became professors, and wrote a paper that was actually rather significant.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cox%E2%80%93Zucker_machine

#Calckey just hit 300 active servers, according to FediDB.

Last month, we had little over 250 servers. Which means that during the past month, nearly 50 active servers have come online.

For any server software on the Fediverse, this is tremendous growth -- and we're excited for what happens next!

@fediversenews

https://fedidb.org/software/calckey

As BGR notices, #Instagram is feeling more and more pressure from the Fediverse -- which is why they've recently started adding features that should have been available a decade ago. I'm talking about GIF comments here.

But if BGR thinks Instagram is facing pressure from #Bluesky and #Mastodon, just wait till #Pixelfed finally releases their Android and iOS apps!

That might change things significantly!

https://bgr.com/tech/gifs-are-finally-coming-to-instagram-comments/

@fediversenews@venera.social

One reason I believe it's more important to emphasize #SpreadFediverse over #SpreadMastodon is because spreading the Fediverse partially addresses the problem of Mastodon churn.

Understand that even if #Mastodon was the best, most intuitive service ever made, there will always be churn because somebody won't like it -- and that's okay.

But when people churn, it's far better for people to move elsewhere on the Fediverse than return to Big Social.

This is a big reason why I'm running https://calckey.social, and why I'm also trying to make it easier for people to start up their own servers through #SpaceHost.

Oh, and it's definitely important that we share news about the greater Fediverse so that churning Mastodon users realize that they have options.

I've seen the "Gifted" #SMBC comic forwarded a few times now: https://www.smbc-comics.com/comic/gifted It's amusing, but what it doesn't say (and what I've seen some smart people miss) is that there is no "green" zone where smarter people no longer have "keen... awareness of own deficiencies" Knowledge is vast; we're human; so we'll always know less than there is to know. Better to accept that (and still learn more of what we can as we want) than to delude ourselves that we can be self-sufficient know-it-alls.

What will production NLP look like, once the dust settles around LLMs? One view is basically “prompts are all you need”. I disagree. I wrote a bit about this when we released #spaCy LLM last week, but the topic deserves its own post, so here it is.

https://explosion.ai/blog/against-llm-maximalism

Big news regarding #SpaceHost!

We've passed alpha and are now moving towards closed beta! In fact, we'll be demoing the platform to a potential customer next week -- and I'm excited!

For those unaware, #SpaceHost is the fully managed Fediverse hosting service that @reiver@mastodon.social and I are running.

Right out of the gate, we'll be hosting a wide array of Fediverse services including #Mastodon, #Pixelfed, #Calckey, #Pleroma -- and others!

I know that so many people have been waiting for this moment. I'm so happy that #SpaceHost is now in closed beta!

If you want to apply for closed beta access, here's where to sign-up:

https://spacehost.one

Section 230 is intact!

This is great news not just for #Twitter and #YouTube but also for the Fediverse.

It means that if something terrible, like a terrorist threat, gets hosted on your server, you are not legally liable for its contents.

And trust me, due to the realities of federation, there will be times when bad material will momentarily hit your server -- even if you're the world's greatest content moderator.

We can all breathe a sigh of relief. That is, for now.

https://www.axios.com/2023/05/18/supreme-court-section-230-twitter-google-youtube

@socialmedianews@venera.social

title: How you want me to cover artificial intelligence

last_post.content:
Several of Casey Newton's rules for covering AI apply equally to academics speculating about it in public (often wildly) https://www.platformer.news/p/how-you-want-me-to-cover-artificial

-Don’t hype things up.
-Emphasize the tradeoffs involved.
-Remember that nothing is inevitable.

A mind-bogglingly disastrous and foolish opinion from the Supreme Court in the Andy Warhol case: artists may be able to create transformative works but they aren't allowed to sell them. It will take decades to calculate the damage this opinion will do. Justice Kagan's dissent is devastatingly brutal.

https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/22pdf/21-869_87ad.pdf

Hey #Fediverse friends! 👋 We're excited to do an #introduction of feedle, a powerful tool we built to help you discover blogs and podcasts with ease. 📰🎧: https://feedle.world/

Our motivation is simple: we want to help you declutter your digital lives and focus on content that truly matters to you. We believe that #RSS is an underutilized gem 💎 that can empower you to break free from the noise of social media.

title: SLiC-HF: Sequence Likelihood Calibration with Human Feedback

last_post.content:
RT @peterjliu@twitter.com

Here is our “slick” RLHF-alternative without RL: https://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10425 (SLiC-HF)

TL;DR: Works as well as RLHF, but a lot simpler.

About as easy and efficient as fine-tuning. Much better than simply fine-tuning on good examples.

From great collaborators: @yaozhaoai@twitter.com,… https://twitter.com/i/web/status/1659023597447565312

🐦🔗: https://twitter.com/peterjliu/status/1659023597447565312

Along with ruling in the #Warhol Foundation vs. #Goldstein #FairUse case, the #SupremeCourt also today issued two unanimous rulings against plaintiffs claiming Twitter and Google were liable for terrorist attacks by groups using their platforms. #SCOTUS opinion in Twitter Inc vs. Taamneh: https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/22pdf/21-1496_d18f.pdf , and per curiam ruling in Gonzalez vs. Google: https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/22pdf/21-1333_6j7a.pdf

I'm over the moon that the #Python helper function I write more than _any_ other, `chunks`, is coming to the stdlib in 3.12 as `itertools.batched(iterable, n)`! It takes a long iterable and yields chucks (or batches) of length `n`.

I think I've pasted the same Stackoverflow snippet into... 10 projects at this point? So this is huge for me.

https://docs.python.org/3.12/library/itertools.html#itertools.batched

Lawyers of Mastodon, when the Supreme Court says that the plaintiffs in Gonzalez v Google have "little claim for relief" does that mean, as I understand, that the Court doesn't think the case offers sufficient evidence for YouTube to be held liable?

If so, then as a scientist working on the question of causality and recommender systems, there's actually quite a lot I can offer to the conversation about the case. But I want to be sure I understand the opinion first.

https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/22pdf/21-1333_6j7a.pdf
